awd_titl_txt: The Effects of COVID-19 on Intimate Partner Homicide Incidence and Risk
awd_abstract_narration:
In addition to the great physical risk posed by COVID-19, the pandemic rapidly transformed our social world. In March 2020, in an effort to curb virus spread, U.S. jurisdictions began to issue stay-at-home policies that asked individuals with non-essential jobs to shelter in place. Although the intent of this effort was to decrease the virus' spread, it may have also resulted in increased exposure to violence in the home, including to intimate partner homicide. By contrast, risk of homicides that typically occur outside the home, such as those perpetrated by strangers or acquaintances, may have decreased due to lessened exposure to the greater community. This study aims to investigate whether stay-at-home policies differentially affected homicide rates, with an in-depth look at how intimate partner homicide and intimate partner violence-related homicide risk was affected by the pandemic. Our theoretical model suggests that, for victims of intimate partner violence and their children, isolating at home could elevate homicide risk simply by increasing the time spent alone with an abusive partner. Additional risk for intimate partner homicide may have also been exacerbated during this time, including firearm acquisition, increased alcohol consumption, and loss of employment. We selected two states for this study, New Jersey (NJ) and Arizona (AZ), as they present an excellent opportunity for comparison. AZ experienced its first surge of the virus later with stay-at-home policies enacted at different times, for shorter periods, and in a less restrictive manner than stay-at-home policies in NJ. This study will contribute to our understanding of the total costs of COVID-19 to our communities and to our most vulnerable groups. 

The goal of this project is to better understand how COVID-19 stay-at-home policies affected homicide risk. The first aim is to understand if the trends in the rates of intimate partner homicide and intimate partner violence-related homicide changed as stay-at-home policies were enacted and to compare these trends with those of other familial and non-domestic homicide. Case file information will be collected from law enforcement and medical examiners to get an accurate count of homicides that occurred in 2020, building upon data previously collected by this research team in AZ and NJ from 2016 to 2019. The second aim is to understand individual-level risk of homicide through qualitative interviews with the next-of-kin of homicide victims who were killed in 2020. During case file data collection, next-of-kin of victims of intimate partner homicide and intimate partner violence-related homicide will be identified and asked to participate in qualitative interviews that explore how COVID-19 and its related policies affected individual-level lethality risk. It is likely that future pandemics will arise, and it is imperative to understand population-level and individual-level risks for intimate partner homicide and intimate partner violence-related homicide in order to develop appropriate theory and prevention interventions, such as protocols for police response.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The COVID-19 pandemic reshaped daily life, impacting patterns of violence, especially domestic violence and homicide. In March 2020, U.S. jurisdictions implemented stay-at-home (SAH) orders, urging citizens in non-essential jobs to remain home to curb virus transmission. While effective for controlling COVID-19 spread, SAH orders likely altered exposure to violence. Confinement may have heightened risks of intimate partner homicide (IPH) and familial child homicides, while reduced community interaction may have led to fewer non-domestic homicides. This study examined the impact of SAH policies on four homicide types (familial, child domestic, intimate partner, and non-domestic) in Arizona and New Jersey. These states enacted SAH policies differently, varying in homicide rates and firearm safety regulations. Arizona’s SAH orders were shorter, less restrictive, and enacted later than New Jersey’s prolonged, stricter measures.

Findings show that pre-pandemic (2016–2019), Arizona and New Jersey had differing homicide trends. Arizona’s homicide rate peaked in 2017, with higher firearm use in IPH cases, whereas New Jersey’s peak was in 2016, with younger victims and lower firearm use in familial homicides. Gender dynamics also varied, as women were primarily IPH victims in both states, although Arizona had a 25% higher rate of male victims in familial homicides compared to New Jersey.

During the pandemic, both states saw surges in gun purchases, though with different timing. Arizona saw a rise in gun purchases during SAH, sustaining high levels through reopening. Conversely, New Jersey’s increase came mainly post-SAH, persisting through fall closures. Unemployment rates doubled in both states during SAH, though New Jersey’s rate remained higher during reopening.

Familial homicide analyses revealed significant differences between Arizona and New Jersey. In Arizona, Poisson regression analysis showed that each unit increase in unemployment was linked to a 28% decrease in familial homicide rates, a pattern not seen in New Jersey, where familial homicide rates were unaffected by unemployment changes. Instead, New Jersey experienced a seasonal rise in familial homicides in June versus January. Arizona’s gun-only models mirrored trends in overall models, improving fit with each nested comparison, whereas New Jersey’s model fit worsened. This inconsistency may stem from varying firearm access or other state-specific influences.

Child domestic homicide patterns also differed between the states. Arizona showed a 28% decrease in child homicide rates with each unit increase in unemployment, possibly tied to heightened family awareness due to economic strain. However, New Jersey revealed fewer significant factors in child homicides, though 2017 rates were notably lower than in 2020. Inconsistencies in New Jersey’s gun-only model estimates may reflect regional firearm access variations or differing reporting practices.

For IPH, Arizona’s regression results indicated a 61% increase in homicide rates per unit rise in unemployment, with reopening periods showing higher IPH rates than SAH periods. In contrast, New Jersey’s IPH models were less consistent, showing no significant relationship between IPH rates, community-level factors, or reopening phases. This discrepancy underscores the need to understand the unique socio-environmental factors affecting IPH risks in different states, possibly due to stronger social networks or policies that mitigated stress during reopening.

Non-domestic homicide patterns varied by state as well. Arizona’s non-domestic homicide rates fell by 9% per unit increase in unemployment, with non-domestic, firearm-related homicides lower pre-COVID. In New Jersey, non-domestic homicides showed seasonal variability, with May homicide rates significantly higher than in January. The time-only model best fit New Jersey’s non-domestic homicides, although effects weakened when other covariates were added, suggesting complex influences.

The study suggests that COVID-19-era homicide trends were shaped by regional, economic, and policy-specific factors, impacting violence types uniquely. Arizona’s pattern of rising unemployment correlating with reduced familial and child homicides suggests a potential “household solidarity” effect during economic hardship, absent in New Jersey. Increased IPH post-lockdown in Arizona may relate to renewed mobility and stress, while New Jersey’s lack of significant change may reflect stronger social networks or protective policies against IPH escalation. Seasonal trends, such as elevated June homicides in New Jersey, support criminological theories linking warmer months with interpersonal conflict due to increased outdoor activity.

Inconsistent gun-only model results, particularly in New Jersey, could arise from differences in firearm accessibility and data practices between states. Arizona’s stable association with non-domestic gun-related homicides suggests firearm availability as a significant factor in state-specific violence. New Jersey’s minimal community-level effects indicate that broader state policies may have a greater influence on homicide rates than local socio-economic factors.

These findings highlight the complex relationship between public health policies and homicide rates during COVID-19, emphasizing the importance of economic resilience in violence prevention during social disruptions. Understanding these dynamics can help policymakers better support communities in maintaining safety amidst broader societal challenges.

 


Last Modified: 11/01/2024
Modified by: Millan A Abinader
